Award.AwardTitle: Chemistry of Atmospheric Aerosols at Pacifichem 2015 Congress Conference in Honolulu, Hawaii; December 15-20, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports a symposium entitled "Chemistry of Atmospheric Aerosols" at the 2015 International Chemical Congress of Pacific Basin Societies (Pacifichem). The symposium will include a diverse group of presentations in the form of invited, contributed, and poster presentations. This will be the second time a symposium devoted to atmospheric aerosols is part of the Pacifichem program and it will provide a unique opportunity for scientists from different countries to gather in one place and discuss the cutting edge advances in the cross-disciplinary areas of aerosol research. The broader impacts of this project will be the sharing of knowledge about current research on atmospheric aerosols related to air quality. Air pollution issues in western Pacific Rim countries are the most apparent examples of the environmental impacts of atmospheric aerosols.

The American Chemical Society, the Canadian Society for Chemistry, the Chemical Society of Japan, the New Zealand Institute of Chemistry, the Royal Australian Chemical Institute, the Korean Chemical Society, and the Chinese Chemical Society are sponsoring the conference. The American Chemical Society is the host society for the 2015 Congress. Pacifichem 2015 will be the seventh in the series of successful cosponsored scientific conferences of Pacific Basin Chemical Societies.

The Chemistry of Atmospheric Aerosols will consist of five half-day oral sessions, two evening sessions, and one poster session. The session topics chosen by the organizing committee are: (1) Chemical composition of atmospheric aerosols, fog and cloud water; (2) Multiphase reactions of aerosols and environmental surfaces; (3) Optical properties of atmospheric aerosols; (4) Impact of aerosols on cloud formation; (5) Frontiers in modeling studies of aerosols; and (6) Frontiers in aerosol analytical chemistry and spectroscopy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atmospheric aerosol particles, also known as “particulate matter”, affect many environmental issues including health effects, air quality and pollution, visibility, and climate forcing at regional and global scales. Understanding the environmental impact of aerosols relies on the fundamental scientific knowledge of the relationship between their chemical composition and their physical properties. Producing new knowledge of this sort increasingly require collaborations between scientists on an international scale.  This proposal was used to support a symposium entitled “Chemistry of Atmospheric Aerosols” at the 2015 International Chemical Congress of Pacific Basin Societies (Pacifichem). This symposium provided a unique opportunity for about 100 scientists from different countries (United States, Canada, Mexico, China, Japan, Korea, Australia, Germany, France, Brazil, etc.) to gather in one place and discuss the cutting edge advances in the cross-disciplinary areas of aerosol research. The “Chemistry of Atmospheric Aerosols” symposium consisted of five half-day (4 hours) oral sessions, two evening (2 hours) sessions, and one poster session. It featured a diverse group of presentations in the form of invited, contributed, and poster presentations. There was plenty of time for the attendees to discuss new ideas and potential collaborations both during the oral sessions and at the poster sessions. The symposium was especially beneficial to graduate student researchers, postdoctoral fellows, assistant professors, and junior researchers whose prior exposure to international aerosol chemistry science had been limited. The symposium provided junior researchers with a much broader perspective of aerosol chemistry than that afforded by attending a national meeting. The graduate student attendees and junior researchers got a chance to network with experts in their area of research and to advance their careers through presentations at a major international conference.
